regretList.regret: Haber estudiado una carrera universitaria para terminar siendo un burocrata y no una carrera para estar la mayor parte del tiempo en el campo.
Seguir haciendo cosas que no me gustan
Más tiempo de calidad y momentos de apoyo y camaradería con mi hermano mayor. Quien lastimosamente murió en un accidente de carro cuando tenía 28 años.

Yo desearia haber estudiado fuera de mi pais y haberme dado la oportunidad de conocer otra(s) cultura. El arrenpentimiento mas grande fue haberme casado joven y no haber aprendido ingles antes de los 25 años.
I wished that I treated people around me that loves me better. That I go ahead with the job in Ireland. That I spend more time with my parents.

Getting angry and isolating myself from my family for most of my teenage lifetime. 

Holding onto the frustration of someone not loving and acting the way I want them to.
I regret not spending my youth doing more meaningful work that builds my self esteem and character
Following what I wanted and not considering enough where that would lead
I regret I focused too much on others well-being that I ignored mine
I wish I had pursued my dream of studying at NYU.
I regret being very impulsive. Though I have no control over it. I won't change too yet the regret would stay.

There is always a better way to handle a situation. Albus Dumbledore in Harry Potter once noted "Words are, in my not so humble opinion, our most inexhaustible source of magic, capable of both inflicting injury and remedying it.". I created pain to others which I should not have done. With some patience and maybe an over night sleep, I would have been in a better shape to handle many situations in my life.
Not doing more clinical/research work and not creating contacts with my professors when I had the chance.
Not losing enough weight
Not having been more social in high school

I regret that I had not given importance to my life rather cared for rest of the world.
I regret that I had not learnt rules of how to succeed in job rather continued doing hard work and being emotional.

I regret that I have not taken care of my health due to fear of losing job 

I regret that I did not invest money.

I regret that I did not loved myself.
Not finding a way to stay back in US because my values are more aligned to that country than my own.
I should have opted my interest area of cyber security field has my under graduation, instead of choosing medicine
I didn’t taken good care of my health
I regret not getting my HS diploma early, and going to college early, as suggested by my HS counselor.
Not recognizing my son's emotional and mental problems when he was young and not knowing what to do
I regret not understanding the value of getting a more marketable degree in college. My mindset focused on what I could achieve success in, rather than starting with what I wanted.

When my best friend of 33 years stopped talking to me out of the blue, I wish I'd just been courageous and driven to meet her face to face instead of waiting, trying to email or contacting her friends to help.  Even if she'd shut the door in my face, at least I'd have had some closure much earlier than the slow grief process that stretched out for months.  I know at the time I thought that might make it worse, but in the end she kept me frozen out anyway, so I wish I'd have taken the risk.  Maybe then I'd have more closure or undertanding for my own sake.
Getting married to quickly without getting to know my husband better.
I regret not doing more than studying and going to classes when I was in college. I wish I had developed a wide circle of friends through extracurricular activities.

When a friend was on a path to making some huge mistakes in her personal life, I wasn't brave enough to confront her because I was her boss.  It had the potential to get sticky legally if I interfered. I ended the friendship and I miss it.

My most significant regret is the manner in which I treated my mother. She tried so hard to protect me from the truth of my fathers (and grand fathers) suicide, while trying to create a family for us in the aftermath.  Her choice of a step father for me was fraught with division, anger and abuse. I could only interpret her actions from my perspective at the time. Now that I am in the waning years of life I better understand. I am thankful however we had 10 days together in Hospice and had many healing moments.

I regret my rampant promiscuity In the early years of my marriage. Little did I know that my hippy husband would mature into a man with middle class values who could never quite trust me, despite fifty subsequent years of fidelity. Nope, it wasn’t worth it!
I regret the choice I made in an undergraduate college.
I regret not having taken time off between college and law school to mature psychologically and emotionally.
I regret not leaving a relationship sooner.
Putting my husband's name on my house.  Lost it in the divorce.
Marrying the wrong person

Not saving valuable baseball cards.
Not investing in something valuable that appreciates.
I wish I had not been so fearful about everything working out ok. I wasted a lot of time on worry and it showed up as anger. My kids were witnesses and I wish I could take it all back.
I regret that I didn't seek mental health treatment for depression sooner.
Harassed a coworker 20 years ago before I realized how stupid it was.  Hard lesson learned but help guide me over years since in my career and thereby helping others.
wasting so much emotional bandwidth being angry and treating those i loved with such disdain.
I wish that I had taken college more seriously the first time around.
Marrying the wrong person at 26
I regret that none of my teachers helped me to discover my passions early on. It didn't happen until I was in my 30s.
Not going to college.

I wish I had never started drinking alcohol. I'm a full blown alcoholic at 57 years old and am deciding whether or not to drink myself to death because I feel so trapped with the AA meetings closed down.

Letting myself drift into things like where to go to college, my first job, my career, life partner. I have not actively managed my life. I have great potential and if actively managed I think I could have been great.

I blindly followed my parents wishes instead of my own desires for an education early in life and was afraid to make family unhappy with me. 
I did not speak my heart in many situations and lost the opportunity later in losing either a work or personal relationship.

I regret not taking advantage of spending time with my grandparents as a child. I resented their presence in my home and their desire to connect with me, and now I'd do anything to get that time back.
Not appreciating my Mother  when she was alive.  Single Mom worked all the time-Dad Vet was 100% disabled.
Moving to another city without my son
tying my self image to my weight challenges which precluded me from doing many things and portraying confidence that I truly was "good enough"
I wish I had not waited so long to have a second child
I regret not believing in myself enough and in my ability to have become a doctor of medicine. I talked myself out of following a dream, because I felt I was not good enough.
I regret not believing in and acting on my abilities. I think I could have lived a bigger life than I have.
Overthinking and not starting projects sooner.

Letting my career slip away when I had kids. I think that would have loved day care, and I wouldn't be struggling to find a job that was truly interesting and challenging now that they are moving on with their own lives..
That I was so resigned to my teenage existential angst for so long, almost to show how smart I was, which wasn’t smart.
I consistently spent more money than I earned.

That I did not leave my husband after he became abusive and was using substances (which he denied). I should have left him early on rather than wait until things had deteriorated further for me and my children.

I regret that I didn't realize earlier how I was shaped by destructive emotions and behaviors in my family of origin. Parallel, or only different by a degree, I wish I had embraced the power of mindfulness/meditation sooner.

It sounds a little silly, but I regret waiting until my kids were in high school to follow through on establishing a "holiday skip day" tradition. They enjoyed having the day off from school to go to a movie and shopping with mom, but they would have really loved it when they were little.

Overall, I regret not making better use of my time. 
I regret not telling loved ones I love them more often; I regret the time I spent working instead of living; and I regret most not taking better care of myself (body, mind and spirit).
Not playing organized basketball, a game that I loved playing as a child and a young adult.
Not telling someone I loved them when I had the chance.
My biggest regret is that I spent all my retirement savings.
Drugs can do harm
Missing out on romantic opportunities because of my shyness, especially when I was young.

1-Not enjoying life at its present moment instead of trying to delay good things (vacation to a dream place, going to a simple concert etc.) with the hope that you will have/ experience those  things when you have money, success, career
2-Not standing up for yourself at work or not demanding your reward expectations at work especially in the beginning of your career (I was extremely naive to think that my hard work would be recognized in terms of money, career growth or relocation preferences )
I regret not applying to the Erasmus programme during University
I regret not learning about the system of the patriarchy sooner, how it hurts me and everyone else, and how to dismantle it.
Not trusting my intuition has led to my most significant  regret which was marrying because I didn’t want to disappoint anyone or rock the boat.

I wish I had gone to grad school sooner. I waited 18 years after getting my Bachelor’s degree to get my Masters degree, and another 18 to get my doctorate at the age of 59. I also regret not becoming a veterinarian.
I wish I moved around more in my 20s, instead I was so sure I'd live in the New York-area forever.
Selling an apartment I owned alone to buy a home with a partner
I regret trusting companies and managers more than myself in my career. I did this out of lack of belief in myself.

I think of regret as something I have or had control over by definition, but when I think about what I regret they are mostly things I don't feel I had control over. Such as not having close, intimate relationships with my parents. This was in large part because of who they are and how they parent. I regret that I didn't find what I'm good at and what I love sooner in life. Also not something I could control (since I certainly tried). Here is a regret I had control over: I regret that I didn't become an anti-racist activist until I was a full-grown adult. That should have started way younger. I also regret that I spent so much energy loving and wanting partners who did not love or want me back.
I regret that I didn’t take my mental health seriously in my 20s and, in doing so, utterly lost my sense of self-worth.
Skipping college
Not staying in a particular job I had when things got tough
For the most part, I haven’t been true to myself and have only done what narcisstic men expected me to do.
Not having a second or third child
Not having more sexual freedom in my 20s
Not spending enough time with my family before I moved to another country. As well as should have pushed myself even harder in school as the brain back than was much more “flexible”
I regret continuing to endure a job for 20 years that I despise, in an industry that I'm exasperated from, because I get paid very well.  I knew I'd feel this way, and didn't change it.
I wish I’d had sex with other men before marrying my husband (my first lover) - still married 48 years later!

I deeply regret not being a mother.  The popular view at the time was that waiting to have children was fine.  Now we know much more about the risks of older women and pregnancy, but in my case it was too late.
I regret that I didn't appreciate my parents more, hug them more and tell them I loved them.

I regret that the high expectations I placed on my son caused him to have anxiety and struggle with confidence. While I don't believe it's my "fault" that he has OCD tendencies and anxiety, I worry that my actions contributed to its development.
I was almost 40 years old when I started to study law. I should have started my studies earlier.
Choosing to live far away from home and not having a support system during a pandemic
Not spending more time with my children's school activities - volunteering and participating more often.
That I got married early at 21 to a 33 year old. I was "in love" and wanted to get on with life. I should have studied music and art for a more fulfilling life.
I regret not making a better effort to generate friendships in college and maintain them after graduating.
I regret not having a child.
I regret not telling him that I liked him. I regret not taking leaps.
I regret worrying so much about what others thought about me in my youth

I wish I had followed an old boss/mentor to the new company she joined, rather than sticking around at the old one.  After staying in my old role, the new boss correctly saw me as one of his predecessor's people rather than his and, as such, my opportunities declined and I was soon let go.  The old boss went on to become one of the industry's leading lights, and would have carried me with her.
Not paying more attention in Irish language classes.
I regret getting angry in the parking lot. I should not have overreacted and lashed out at her like that.
I regret not applying behaviour science earlier in my career.

Treating someone I loved badly.  Trying to change someone I loved , the person was perfect the way they are , that's why I fell in love with them in the first place.   Now I have major regret as we are no longer in each others lives.

There is not one specific incident I am considering; rather, I have regrets about about my general attitude towards other people and wish I had been more graceful.  As a youth, I lacked awareness of other people's feelings and perspectives, which led me to inconsiderate behaviour.
Left the business I helped build thinking I could just do it again, but in sunny California instead of Canada
I regret not taking my mental health more seriously in university. It took most of my 20s to fully recover from depression.
Immature actions at a younger age

I didn’t pursue an education in ECE because my father said the salary was low yet I was accepted based on my idea of creating child care centres in factories which later happened. I wonder how that might have panned out.
I wish I had gone to University.

Not being kinder to employees earlier in my career due to a lack of understanding and empathy. 
Regret not reading The Four Agreements sooner as it was life changing.
I regret not thinking more about the people close to me and their needs when I was younger.    I wish I hadn't been so self centered.
Not taking risks earlier
I regret not finishing my Ed.D. in Curriculum and Instruction. I don't think it's held me back, but gosh I would love to have it.
Not taking more "risks" -- or things I saw as "risks" at the time. Being too timid and not bold enough in actions.

Separating from employment with the University of Florida in 1986 to pursue starting a business of my own. I traded security and surety for risk with very little return on investment, financially and socially. It set precedent for future career endeavor patterns leading to the present.
Nothing. Life is too short to have regrets.
Not taking changes earlier in my life and career.

I regret quitting training so much to go back to full time work. Working more didn’t make me wealthier, and now I didn’t reach my goals, lost my athleticism and gained 20 pounds, but mostly I was a lot happier before and a lot less stressed.
I regret not studying harder in high school, college and graduate school. I did fine career wise but missed out on a lot of learning
I took care of my mom for over 30 years and I am sure she knew I loved her but I regret not telling her more often than I did.
Not forgiving, not connecting with family more.
Putting so much pressure on college instead of experience in the field.
I regret not taking better care of myself emotionally. I should have ended a relationship sooner.
I regret not keeping in touch with certain friends from my past.

Not setting boundaries earlier in life which meant working too much and not being clear on what I wanted in relationships. I listen to my body now if I should or shouldn’t be doing something, whether it’s work or personal, and it’s made such a difference.

Not being more confident in my abilities, when interacting with others. Being less present in the moment, was the reason. That made my interpersonal interactions dull and affected by ability to influence others. Also, that made me fickle and affected by resilience at work. Although, I am fortunate that things turned out good, but I could have aimed much higher. I will display more confidence in 2021.
Having a child
not prioritizing my mental health sooner

I regret not taking the time to develop and nurture friendships earlier on in my life. Comparison is the thief of happiness, and my pursuit of accomplishments took precedence over building relationships. Judge your life by your friendships and lives you have truly touched, not material status and possessions.
I regret not speaking my mind and making my opinions on important matters known sooner in my relationship with my ex spouse.
To stay in the present
That I didn’t take more time to work on my writing, that I didn’t focus more on my weight and health.

The first is that I believed the narrative that I wasn't good enough to be an impact player on my high school basketball team - it led to playing tentatively and with fear of failure, and the result was I under-performed and Iost my starting job. 

Next, not prioritizing my career in my 20's.
I wish I had more children; what could be bad about having more people to love?
I wish I had taken the arts administration internship instead of the one in government. I might have a career better suited to my personality now.
Having sex too early
Dropping out of law school.
I wish I got a specific professional certification that I needed for advancement.
Not starting a family sooner. Was able to have one child but infertility prevented us from having another.

Not getting to know my father before he died. He wasn’t  a very talkative guy and I came along later in life. I spent most of my teens found teenager things, went away to university, and came home intent on launching.  In the arrogance of youth, I paid little attention to his mortality. He died just after my 30th birthday. I wish I’d had the foresight to spend more time asking questions.

Most regret 'falling for' my ex-husband's b.s. during our divorce. Largely due to this, and I will admit I had some part in this---however, I had been cheated on after 24 years of faithful marriage. Now I wouldn't want a husband, but I have no daughter nor her wife, either
not being as empathetic or patient as I could have been with my mum who is now gone
Not standing up for myself in a relationship, needing to have stronger boundaries for myself

That i allowed others to guide my life and i did not put my foot down and say "these are my needs and they should be met".  Instead i looked after meeting everyone's needs before mine.  Whilst it was great to be a giver sometimes you need to learn how to be accepting and be a "taker/receiver of love, affection, pleasure, physical items and emotions".
Not putting aerospace engineering down as my first uni choice. I studied business instead, but had the grades to literally be a rocket scientist.
I wish I had planned my career more.
I wish I had sex with more people. I have lots of long relationships, wish I had had a few more shorter spontaneous ones.
Not returning to team sports as soon as my children arrived.  Took me another 10 years!

Not embracing my time in the Navy, not investing in becoming a pilot, trusting people, devoting my time to causes with no successful outcome.  I am as Hirroditus describes, one who knows so much, yet control nothing
Not being more honest earlier with myself and the relationships around me

Not sure I have significant regrets... I wish I had moved in with my husband before we got married, but would consider this a "wish i did" because overall happy with the outcome. Everything else in life I am glad to have learnt because they taught me alot

not being more content and appreciating what i have
living in Paris
Not establishing a career before getting married and having a child.

I was admitted to a PhD program few years ago and chose a charismatic and well known professor to be my supervisor. From the very beginning of our collaboration, she was continuously giving me critical feedback and my work was never good enough for her. I thought the problem was in me. So I worked harder, kept trying, but I kept receiving critical feedback, and in many instances I felt disrespected. One day I decided that's enough, I decided that I was not going to waste any more years trying to change the perception of someone who obviously did not believe in me. I picked another professor to work with and since then my experience has been much better. I still receive critical feedback on my work, but the critical feedback that I am receiving now is helping me improve my work and improve my competences. I regret having spent so many years working under the supervision of someone who did not believe in me and who did not see me as capable
Choosing the wrong mentor
I regret not playing soccer as a youth.

I regret not spending more time nurturing and maintaining friendships and developing more in person long-term relationships. Now I am 54 in a pandemic living alone and dealing with the realization of how short life is.
Regret being absent and alone when family, friends and colleagues needed my presence. Still work-in-progress.
I regret not having more pasta nights with friends in 2020

I took an interest survey when I was 23 and it indicated that I was interested in and had a personality conducive to the work of an archeologist. At the time I didn’t see a financially viable future there so I went with studying psychology.....should have chosen archeologist.

I regret not exploring my sexuality when I was in my teens and 20s. I had opportunities and spurned them out of fear, I guess. In my 50s I came to appreciate my bisexuality. If had explored it, I might have made the same choices or very different ones. I’m happy with how my life turned out, but I can’t help wondering...
Spending most of my life focusing on others instead of what makes me happy
Not starting a self-directed retirement plan in my 30s.
Not giving my time and money to help those in need
Having an abortion. Having to say I’m so sorry when I meet him/her in Heaven. Sigh...

I regret placing my family and work obligations in front of building and maintaining lasting friendships.  I also regret any time I didn’t stick to my core values, those decisions usually had unfortunate consequences.
My biggest regret is living by the rules and not having as much fun in my life.
Not listening to that little inner voice that was screaming at me to keep my mouth shut. I have often ignored it and deeply regretted it every single time.
Failed to stop and help a young woman in her car with a baby on a bridge in Manhattan
Not being more assertive
Getting married when I shouldn’t have

I regret two things: 1- wasting my time with unresourceful people, doing unnecessary things (social media, news reading,...), working with unproductive teams; 2- missing to build a strong social and professional network at my 20s age.

Time is priceless and it cannot be recovered. if wasted for no personal gain (emotion, social, financial) then it leads to wasted life.
xxxxxxxxxxx
Not forging a stronger relationship with my only daughter. I put too much emphasis on wanting her to be strong and independent and lost a special closeness I wish for today.
I regret not forming more solid relationships in high school and college. I feel like I’ve lacked the ability to truly engage with other people my age into adulthood because of it.
I didn't ask Miss WHS 1982 for a date...

1) thinking bigger is better in so many things/ways.
2) not expanding myself into the community civically and business involvement

Instead of writing as a first career, which I've wanted to do and trained to do since my teens, I've continuously chosen stable work as a teacher. Plan A got precious few hours as I sank my energy into plan B.
I regret not having asked for help when I needed it. I took on burdens that would have been easier to carry if I had showed my vulnerability and need for help
To haven't had any experience abroad during university or immediately after

I regret for not having had the courage to accept a job proposal abroad. 
I work for a French bank in Italy and some years ago I was proposed to move to Seoul and start an International career path. I do not know why I started focusing on what I would have lost (friends, parents, my children schoolmates,....) instread of what I would have obtained (more money and possibility of a metter l’idea, new expetiences, new friends... ) with this move.
Result: I am 52 and have  been in the same job and place for 20 years now and would like to have a change but the current situation (economic crises, pandemic...) as well as my age and my salary make this almost impossible.
If I had been more aware of the consequences of my actions I may not have upset some people
I could not keep my family together

To live abroad when I was a student.
To travel more outside Europe before having had children
I regret not having obtained the motorcycle license
Not following my gut and being honest with myself. I always knew what my talent was but I let other people influence my decisions instead
I regret following my dick rather than my head and losing out on raising my daughter.
Retraining to be a Teacher and leaving my old Corporate Coaching and Leadership roles; when I had my Son.

It’s silly, but I wish I had learned French at school and could speak it fluently. I speak other languages but not French, yet France is a country I am drawn to and really love, maybe it’s not too late.
Taking the time to search and appreciate art in a way that is restful and filling.
Not spending more time with my kids when they were younger. Now that I have a Grandchild I appreciate the fun that can be had together.

I regret that due to living across the globe from my parents, I was not there to help them when first my dad, and then after his death, my mum developed dementia based illnesses. I flew home to see them as often as I could, the last times, not realising how close to passing they were. Both died a within a week of me returning back to the UK from New Zealand, Dad in 2014, Mum in 2018.
I regret staying at jobs that were not fulfilling to me and that did not utilize my strengths and prioritizing work rather than traveling more often.
I stayed in an unhealthy relationship for much longer than I should have and wasted many good years of my life.
Using alcohol as an outlet for grief and pain
None actually
I had an abortion years ago
That i didnt say i love you earlier
Compromising relationships with people that compromised personal integrity with loved ones.
I regret I didn’t have a stronger sense of myself , with accompanying confidence so I could do the right thing and not let fear or insecurity block me from saying the hard thing or taking a risk.
I did not set our family up for financial success when we were all younger.
Wish I had spent more time with my parents

A regret that still plagues me is my decision to live safely, follow a boyfriend, and go to a commuter college.  I missed the experience of taking risks, learning more about myself and making friends for life.
The hurt I caused my wife at the start of our relationship.
I regret getting married in college, far too young and clearly to the wrong woman. It was a profound distraction and made school more stressful than it should have been.
I regret picking up drinking
I regret not being present for my children.  I was always worried about money and could have loved them better and paid more attention to them.
Because I engage in serial non-monagomy I have never had the spell of oneness with my husband.
Not running for my safety when I had a chance. I knew I was in trouble and was too scared to run; as a result, I was raped.

In the grand scheme of my life I have no regrets. Had I done anything differently I would have gone off the path that was meant just for me and I wouldn’t be in the exact spot I am today. Excepting the good and the bad is all part of self actualization. We need the Ying and yang.

After my spouse died, I moved out of our house, but didn't do the work to get the house on the market for so long that it became a burden on me rather than a place filled with happy memories and a profit from selling it.
The relationship I ruined before I knew I had achd.
Focused too much on my professional career while my no 1 priority should have been my kids. I didn’t develop the bond which I should have when they were young.
Not cheated on my wife
Not taking my marriage seriously enough and not seeing my husband's misdeeds sooner.

Not being quicker to level up in my work. I stayed in an industry that was declining in North America longer than I should have. Making the move earlier would have enabled me to progress more quickly in a growing industry.

I regret not working harder in college, and then grad school;  I took the easy route when working harder earlier would have made the rest of my life so much easier.  I regret not having more children.  They're a lot of work the first 10 years, but are really rewarding after that initial phase.
Giving in to a partner after saying no many times
Following my father's advice to get a degree in business instead of studying what I was interested in.
not doing a semester abroad in college

I regret not taking my early education more seriously. I am so much smarter than I had given  myself credit for! 
By parenting my two daughters, I also inadvertently parented myself, realizing how to better educate us all. Lucky for my kids; a bit too late for me. My kids are better educated and will no doubt end up with better and more satisfying careers.  I did end up becoming an RN, but only by default. It was not the best choice for me.
Not being a better father.

Not sticking with track sports in high school for a bit longer.  Not taking a gap year between high school and college to spend a year in Israel.  Neither of these are significant now. But I would certainly add, like I suspect for many others:   the regrets are more about what I did not take a chance to do, than regrets about things I did and then regretted.  One of my favorite quotes:     There is no comparison between that which is lost by not succeeding and that which is lost by not trying.
no children
Having a relationship with someone that could have significantly hurt a close friend

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: I don’t have a significant regret.

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: Not getting into my first choice university

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: Walking away, not facing up to people

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: Being too timid to take the opportunities life has offered me. Choosing security over excitement.

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: That I was confident and brave enough in my earlier years to have acted on my instincts more often

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: My brother has suffered from mental health issues for many years. I wish I'd helped him more at the beginning of his ordeal when he was still a teenager.

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: Not moving house to increase value of investment earlier in life

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: I made a bad investment decision against my better judgement and ignoring my reservations.

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: I wish I had been more courageous and stood up to my parents and not tolerated their narcissistic behaviour. I was way too compliant which has caused me much heartache and pain.

location.country: United Kingdom of Great Britain and Northern Ireland

regretList.regret: not going in the army to train discipline
Being overly kind with people who didn't deserve it
Marrying my first wife
Not taking the effort to apply for a top tier university
At one point I was very nervous and resigned.
I wish I had had more confidence in myself and knew I could be loved
not taking enough actions for myself earlier
I work for a research institute that never takes into account my research results on employees' motivations and asks me to spread my research to businesses, it is crazy !!!!
I regret getting married
Wasting time
I regret not being more enterprising and multifaceted during my early 20's. That laid the foundation for lack of diversity in my later career.
As the oldest sibling I felt responsible for the well-being of my brothers. My bossiness pushed them away. I regret not showing more love and understanding.

I regret not pursuing the woman who showed great love for me and who I felt would be a great wife because I didn't feel I measured up to her abilities and commitment. She had so many wonderful attributes and was so right but I didn't see it at the time and that was a huge mistake. I married another woman and was deeply disappointed and eventually divorced her. It has bothered me for many years.
I moved from Singapore back to the United States to be with my now husband. He had promised me we’d move back, but 7 years later he still has yet to hold up his promise
Not listening to myself when I had second thoughts about the girl I married 33 years ago. Settling for pleasure.
Not spending more time with my mother.

I regret not having a good circle of friends.  I grew up in an isolated, oppressive environment and didn’t develop good social skills. I have been uncomfortable as long as I can remember in social and work settings. Acquaintances I have never become more. My regret is not fixing this...when you’re older new relationships are even harder to obtain.
I regret not addressing conflict with people sooner - both in personal and professional settings.  It's the greatest character flaw I have.  At the age of 51, it's the skill I'm working hardest at.

I regret not being light-hearted often enough with loads of chuckling & laugher.  The second regret is not to have become proficient in Spanish. But, hope reigns, I'm alive, healthy & can overcome both regrets starting yesterday !!!
I regret running away from an earlier relationship when I got scared instead of looking at my feeling and working on it.

I regret reacting negatively when I found out my daughter-in-law mentioned to my husband that she and my son were immigrating back to her home in Australia after we were led to believe she wanted to live near us. The left and are now estranged.
Saying no to social gatherings before the pandemic.
Not getting married and having child earlier in life
I wish I had studied something different in university
Study psychology.

Nearly 30 yrs ago studied for 12 hours for a final in college. Two classmates had gotten a hold of the final the day before and asked me to give them answers. For some reason I did and I’ve regretted it since. I was so losses at myself immediately after and still wonder what the hell 20 yr old me was thinking.
I had an extramarital affair.
the way I end relationships
Marrying someone because I felt I had to, but didn't want to.

I regret not having the opportunity to be alone with my mother after she died. I had no opportunity to sit by her to remember, grieve, thank, take in the reality of her death. Funeral arrangements were orchestrated by others and at age 25 I did not feel empowered to ask for what I wanted or maybe even to realize what I needed. There was no private or public reviewal...just a small church service and the burial. The regret has stayed with me for over 50 years.

I got a scholarship to study contemporary Jewish life in Berlin the summer after I graduated from college. I didn't do it because I had landed a full-time job in my field (a big lift when you have a History degree) and couldn't get the time off but if I could do it again, I would quit that job and spend the summer in Germany. I've been to Berlin several times since but would have loved to experience it in that specific context.
Not being more open with a boss/friend about reasons I was leaving his business to start my own because I didn't want to hurt his feelings. Completely ruined the relationship beyond repair.
I regret not being wise or curious enough to ask my father more questions about his life before he suddenly died at age 68, 28 years ago.
Not practicing tennis with enough commitment in my teens.
I regret to be uncertain and not more self-confident in my early 20s. A (better) plan or idea for life would have had helped...

I'm now 84 years old and realizse that I  should have spend more time with my family. They (wife plus three kids) never complained and we are a happy family - but I would have given them more (and received more) by following my career less vigorously.
I would like to have studied a science like biology or geology.
I should have invested early and more wisely
To be honest, I don't have any regrets. Yoga and spiritual practice helped me with the past ones, and I choose well ever since.

Deciding to move out of a rental house that I loved deeply just to save some money by moving in with a friend. It made the next year and a half of my life very difficult housing wise and I still love and miss that house and wish I had never left it. You can leave things too soon and that can be just as damaging as staying somewhere for too long. I learned that assuming you can technically afford something, don’t give it up just out of fear that you won’t be able to save enough money. Peace and happiness far outweigh a certain amount of extra savings or feeling like you “should” do something a certain way.
I regret I talked or gave an opinion when I should have stayed quiet and just listened.
Going to college
Not reconciling my relationship with my father before he died.
Not going to college after high school.  I did eventually get both a bachelors and masters degree but it was so much harder as a working adult.
Ignoring the warning that could have only been meant for me.
Not pursuing the major in college I was not only most passionate about and but know I could have excelled in too.

I wish I would have said yes more often to my mom when she asked for a favor. She asked me to take her to a memorial service and I was feeling overwhelmed with two small children and a busy career I felt I could not emotionally handle it. But, my Mom didn't ask for much and I wish I would have just said yes more often.
Did not give as much effort in college.
When someone shows you who they are, believe them the first time
I regret waiting - waiting for certainty, waiting for permission, waiting for others to lead.
Not having applied myself when I was younger to mastering (10,000 hours and such) real skills.
Nothing at all

At 57, I recognize I should have taken better care of my health to include diet, exercise when I was younger.  A weekly health routine would have extended my life and I would have had a less steep climb at 57.  Health as we age becomes primary and without your health all of what you worked for to get here can be diminished.
I regret that I did not learn to study until far too late to do well in college.
I put work in front of my family. I believed that a meritocracy existed when, in fact, it doesn't.  And that's a huge regret.
Not respecting my father stories of his WWII heroics
Leaving a career I was passionate about because I thought I needed to get on with my life and be more "serious."
Not having a second child.
I regret being angry with my husband the day before I had to take him to the ER. He died the next day from Covid-19.
I wish I had known the importance of finding my life's purpose when I was much younger, rather than 38 y/o. I didn't think critically enough about my life's trajectory early on.
I let relationships define me as a young person.  I didn’t figure out or care about what I wanted, I just wanted to keep the other person happy.
I regret that I have not remained in shape consistently throughout my life.
Didn't stick with consistent physical activity or competitive sports
I did not become a coach and a teacher.

My biggest regret will be not having the courage or making the time to talk with more people about God and what is the true meaning of life.  I have known so many people who the world would say is successful and yet, they end their careers without having a true identity in something bigger then themselves.
That I didn't try harder in school to master subjects that were difficult for me.
Learning more from my father before he died
staying with the wrong person too long

I regret not getting married in front of my mother.  My husband to be was in the military and we had to get married fast and in Oklahoma, which is far from Ohio.  She was very ill and died a month later.  I could have given her happiness of seeing me married and I selfishly didn't work to make that happen.
Had more kids

My husband had 75% oxygen saturation on a Portland OR to Chicago flight because pulmonologist wouldn’t give an oxygen bottle. He got DVT immediately then a blood thinner induced hematoma that took 1/2 his blood volume and a four month hospital and rehab system. Three years of worsening health later he passed away. I regret not asking for in flight oxygen to support him.
I regret not learning to play piano or guitar. Music is such an enjoyable part of my life. Listening to it is wonderful, but I wish I could play one of these versatile instruments.
I had an opportunity to coach at the college level but pasted it up

I moved overseas for two years, bringing a lot of my precious things with me and I regret not bringing those things back when I moved back to USA. My most treasured books and journals were lost to me when the person who was holding my things for me never shipped them as promised. I stopped journaling as a result.

When I was growing up, I thought that gaining accolades, independence, and winning (awards, scholarships, GPA) were the most important things to strive for.  Because of that, family connections took a back seat.  Now that I am older, I don't have very close relationships with any of my relatives.
Living in my hometown my entire life. This has limited opportunities and had led to a lack of diversity and worldly knowledge.

I regret not enjoying my beautiful young body in my 20’s . It is a cliche but so true that a good body is wasted on you when you are younger . How i would appreciate that body now in my 50’s . Great point to always appreciate what you have.

I was offered a full-time job after completing a 3-month residency abroad and turned it down to pursue further studies instead. I dropped out after 2 years, and have always wondered what would have happened if I had taken the job instead.
Not being able to foster strong human connections
I regret having had too many parties
I regret not to start a conversation with a girl o was enlices with at the time.
I take everything as a challenge and lessons to be learned in life, therefor I think I do not regret nothing. at least not now.
no haber dicho te quiero a mas personas, no haber compartido mas tiempo con mi familia.
For sure the biggest regret i have not to have had a child earlier in my life and now not having a choice.
Marrying the person I did.
Herir a las personas que quiero con mis actos o palabras.
Getting married soon after college, selling myself short.
Drinking too much in high school and undergraduate
I wish I would have married out of love instead of thinking I could be a rescuer  to my ex-wife.

I’m 56 as of 12-20-20. At 46, I became the target of a workplace bully. In that phase I read “A whole New Mind”. I followed the link for the empathy test and scoring 21 first time and 19 the second time. I discovered I was on the Autism Spectrum and that changed me, my relationships, everything improved. Turns out, it was the “Beam in my eye”.

I regret I didn’t learn that when I was a child like they do today.
Not divorcing a mentally cruel spouse
Not finishing my masters degree program.
Not pursuing a career earlier in life
I regret not having started saving for retirement earlier.
I wish I would have been more proactive in my infant’s health as a new mom.
I regret not applying myself harder to get into an ivy league graduate school.

That I didn’t have the courafe to go out and find out if the great love of my life was out there - or home here! 
Not pursui g the dream og becoming a writer or journalist
Several regrets about moving too quickly to new thing instead of sticking with and getting great at what I really loved

My only regret is being incredibly hard on myself, not giving myself grace. Everything else that has happened for me in life has brought me here to this point, so I don't regret any of it other than being my own worst critic.
Working too much - giving too much of me to my job
I regret spending too much time focusing on work & not on my family.
Staying in a college major that has never been the right fit for me. I’ve fought my entire professional career hating what I do and trying to break out of the box it has out me in.
That I didn't figure out my anxiety much earlier and get appropriate education and treatment.
Not taking a more proactive stance again our blatant: wealth & income disparity, aggression, militarism, plutocracy & oligarchy (in my strong opinion we have both).
Spent more time talking 1:1 with my kids when they were young.
I regret not prioritizing myself and my future when I was younger. I put others' needs above my own and did not set myself up for success.
I regret not recording the stories my grandfather used to tell. They were wonderful life lessons and I remember a lot of them, but it would be nice to hear him tell the story.

I wish I had more children. After having two, my mother-in-law told me I wouldn't have any more because kids wouldn't fit into our life - we were both working full time. My husband said we could have more, but most of the responsibility would fall on my shoulders. I always wanted a big family and now I regret I didn't make the decision to have more.
Not standing up for myself more often.
Watching too much television.
Not learning more about my family history. I have so many unanswered questions, and now there isn't anyone to ask them.

Not listening to my own misgivings about signing the loan agreement to open a restaurant. My partner and I had a god plan but we let others influence us in the wrong, and ultimately disastrous direction.
not working harder in school
Not living life more honestly.  Waiting 18 years to get help dealing with a sexual assault.
I regret not having gotten divorced sooner. I put up with things well past the point I knew they were never going to change.
I regret I didn’t get to travel the world and experience different cultures, food and people.  Most of all I regret not seeing Paris!
Not having gone to college boarding/prep school. I may have learned to love learning earlier.

I wish I had put more thought into my major at college. A career assessment test would have been so valuable for me because I chose a major that others thought would be good for me instead of one that would help me land a job that I would excel at and enjoy.
That I didn't start reading sooner
Not having the courage to do t my way in my twenties.
Not to spend enough time with my mother before she has passed away and my first kid when he was growing up.
I regret getting the Fulbright award; I took it because it was prestigious and ignored my happiness.
I regret not starting over younger.
I gave up on a relationship with a woman who I wanted to marry because I thought she was through with me.  I should have fought for the relationship instead of immediately given up.
I wish I had quit drinking earlier
I wish I had left my first job out of college sooner than I did. I stayed because I didn't think I could be hired into another role at a new company.
Not asking more questions of older relatives regarding their lives,what it was like for them as a child, relatives they knew that I didn't etc...
Not having spent more times with our children when they were growing up.

I regret that I did not establish practices early on that focused on long-term health, wellness, and success. My attempts to improve myself and help others have largely failed because I never established enough influence through sustained positive efforts, which left my fate in the hands of others.
Not having kids sooner. By late 30's, chances drastically reduce with age.

I'm 65. I wish I had gotten an MFA from a good school, in addition to the MBA that launched my business career. I've always loved novels, have written two and am writing another, but I feel certain I'd be much better at it if I'd had some learned company along the way.
I regret being friends with someone
I regret that I didn't take more chances professionally.  I'm now retired and wonder if I now have the stamina to start trying to make a real difference.
Wish I would have quit sports
My husband died of covid-19 in April.  I wish I had told him more often that I loved him.
The regret i have is the chance i didn't take.  I chickened out of auditioning for an off broadway musical.  To this day I think it would have changed the whole course of my life.
Having driven under influence
I wish I had spent more time as an adult with my amazing grandmothers.

I worked 60 hours a week at my job to keep getting promoted over a 45 year career. It wasn't worth the sacrifice to my family and probably made little difference to my career. More time spent with family , friends , and developing other interests would have been immensely more satisfying.
I married the wrong person and missed the right one

Done an MBA from a reputed university. 
Finished school and started working earlier.

I regret leaving my girlfriend alone in a bar thinking she was safe with these nice guys who were in town for a basketball game. They told us about their wives and kids, showed us pictures of them. One even sent me a Facebook request. When I left I asked them to look out for her. She ended up being drugged and gang raped by them. They were never convicted.
Breaking up with a boyfriend I loved.
Not being able to realize that sometimes the toxic people in your life can be your family.
I regret not working harder in school, and relying on the grades I got when I didn't have to study. This didn't work out so well for me in the end.
Not investing in a property during the recession

Leaving a good job with a fantastic work culture out of my own impatience, rather than just waiting a few months for the opportunity to progress. I think that was the single most career-damaging decision I made, and I've struggled to get back on my feet and into a good job ever since.

As a school pupil, I wanted to go to an evening concert at the school. My (now late) dad agreed to take me. Once we got there, I spotted some friends sat up near the front, and asked my dad if I could go sit with them, leaving him alone for the whole show, sat with other parents he didn't know. I now see this as a miserable experience for dad, as well as a missed opportunity for some quality father-son time – something I can never get back.
I regret not travelling more, being more adventurous and stepping outside my comfort zone
I regret initially training to be a teacher, as it really was not what I was meant to be.

Not trusting myself in my career. Doubting my ability.  This manifested in a way that meant / means I have been more comfortable to sit under the radar and / or under someone’s authority. I could feel safe that way but really not reaching my potential
had a child
I was attracted to a girl called Angela Davis in college but never did anything about it.
Not trying harder to get my children into sports

My dad passed away at the family home in the presence of his family. My mum unfortunately died alone in hospital during the night. My sisters and I (still) regret we weren't present.  Nobody should die alone...
I regret not getting time off from work in order to attend my sister-in-law’s wedding and my friend’s funeral. I placed work above both of these events.

I wish I'd sought help sooner for post-partum depression after the birth of my daughter. I didn't feel well, struggled to breast feed, felt an absence of joy, and was ashamed of my detached feelings towards her. Sadly I lost two years of both my life and hers.
Sometimes over react
Working instead of spending time with family
Listen to the lies I tell myself.
I regret not taking risks and learning it’s ok to fail at an earlier age. I might’ve started challenging myself much earlier.
Not being 1000% honest at all times
Not playing a collegiate sport
Learned how to handle money at an earlier age. And not let it have so much power over me.
I regret that I didn't pursue a Teaching Degree to teach Art
I regret leaving my first marriage.

Not asking for professional help when I struggled academically and psychologically during my first attempt at going to college, straight out of high school. I thought my problems were due to a lack of effort and did not realize I was suffering from a mental illness.
I wish I had been less shy and afraid to take chances when I was a young person. As a grown adult, I am outgoing and extroverted. It's much more fun to be a confident person.

Staying in a bad marriage too long.
Not owning my knowledge and expertise by speaking up more.

I regret that I didn't pursue more education, self-learning, or push myself academically as I am intellectually capable of much more than I have accomplished.  I could have accomplished more - had more impact - if I had access to more intellectuals tools and models available to my thinking.  I wish I had learned more so I could build a better case for the ideas I believe to be good for all.  More education or knowledge may have allowed me to better identify and use my talents.
I regret that I didn't take better care of my teeth, and that I didn't start saving money earlier.

Not spending more time with my dad after learning of his terminal illness. He was doing ok for a while, then all of a sudden he wasn't, and I was too far away to get home in time before he died. That was 20 years ago and still regret not seeing and talking to him one last time (at least).
Not studying harder during my first two years in college. I ended up transferring home, a great university but my degree program had horrible professors.
Not being emotionally present enough when my children were growing up
Saved earlier
I did not buy a beach house as my wife had concerns
I often regret the amount of time I spend working.

An employee had a drinking problem and died from alcohol related disease at age 39. I knew her husband, too, and I regret I did not talk with him about how well she hid her drinking problem. At her funeral her husband said to me, "I didn't know how bad it was."
I wish I had enough strength and confidence to leave a bad relationship.  My life turned out just fine because I did finally leave, but I regret not doing it sooner.

Getting married and changing my plans about grad school. When the marriage fell apart the final semester of college, I had to rush into the first place I could get into to maintain my immigration status.
Not trusting myself, my strengths, and my talents at a younger age.
I regret starting a business with my best friend. The business succeeded but I lost that friend forever.
Not going to college
I had a very easy time getting pregnant and birthing my three children. I regret not having more children.

I regret my selfishness in objecting to my mom taking my dad, who has PD, to the US for Christmas last year.  It's a long story, but  my mom died in May and my brother & sister-in-law cannot come to Canada because of Covid.  It would have been the last time they had seen my mom, and possibly my dad too.

I began attending university in 1988 to become an interpreter. I scored top marks in my langauge classes and was even invited to interview with the Government of Canada Foreign Services Department and write the entrance exam. Then, for a reason I can't even remember now, I changed direction and became a high school social studies teacher instead. I LOVE my job and my family life now, but I can't help but regret not pushing forward and trying this initial career choice. It's one of the 'what if' moments in my life that stands out.
Super regret publishing an engagement announcement that was not true, thought it was funny. Until I stayed sober a few days -- and THEN. Then I sure had regrets.

That I did not find a way to support my keen interest in attending university to become a teacher after graduating from high school.  Our family did not have money, and this was before the days of "student loans."  There could have been another way but I did not pursue the goal hard enough.
I regret teasing my brother during his high school years because I think I went a little too far because of the jealousy I held towards him.
Maybe practice basketball more when I was younger so that I will be better today. Also to try to learn a third language

One regret I have is not taking more opportunities and trying different things or joining certain activities since there might have been something I really excelled at or I could have formed important friendships.
less procrastination and more eagerness
Having dated my first boyfriend because it destroyed me emotionally and mentally.
I regret falling in love with someone that clearly didn't love me back. I regret treating him with kindness, respect, and forgiveness when he didn't deserve it, because I just ended up getting hurt.
Enjoying the moment
I regret not learning how to read music/play an instrument. I realize now it is a valuable skill that's good for you even if you are not into music.
I regret not getting more involved in sports and other activities and not taking advantage of the opportunities I have been given in various stages of my life.
I regret not starting my sport earlier and not trying harder back then.
I wish after grad school I would not have rushed back to my hometown and had seized the opportunity to live overseas
I regret not fighting this kid Ray in the summer of 1991.  I walked away and always regretted not standing up for myself.

I regret than during the years my father suffered from frontal lobe dementia in a nursing facility, I did not take the time to write down the wonderfully creative stories he was telling when we came to visit. His inhibitions towards creativity were gone.
I regret not going to Sweden as an IFYE in 1980.

Talked more with my dad before he passed away. 
Been more vulnerable with husband to try and save marriage.
I do not regret anything because I believe whatever happened with me happened for good and if I ever become successful, all moments of my life will get the credit.
Being too harsh with people close to me when we differed deeply on important issues.
ㄹㄹㅁㅈㅇㅊㅌㄴㄱ호
sgdzfgdsdfgadgfdgfdagfdsgds
Regret not having gotten closer to dad. Wish I had been being more expressive towards him. Wish I was more focused in life - too distracted and always procrastinating.
Not following my passion
I wish i had read more during highschool and college. I wish I were more courageous in my childhood.
I regret drinking alcohol in highschool and in my early 20s
I regret that I did not attend the psychology faculty
I didn’t focus on family and I choose to focus on job and profesional life.

I regret being self-centered and selfish until my 40's, and basically wasting time on my my looks- that said, I strangely regret not allowing myself to buy nice clothes when I was truly young and beautiful!! I regret not taking my reputation seriously- now I have a terrible one and I can't get it back. I regret not having kids earlier in life. I regret all the years of selfish journaling, wasted time I could have been reading OTHERS' work! I regret NOT GETTING INVOLVED, not participating in general. Avoiding things and people. MOST OF ALL regret not keeping up my friendships and close relationships all along. Lastly, Facebook. I regret that I never embraced it? It could have been a way to maintain my friendships better.

I regret not realizing I have choice and other people’s happiness or survival isn’t my responsibility. I spent a lot of time in my 20’s & 30’s being concerned with everyone else and not as much with myself. Just because someone wants to date / marry me doesn’t mean I have to agree.
I can’t think of any significant regrets. I’ve had a wonderful life.

I regret listening to my mother and not following my heart's desire to become a teacher. She told me she would not pay for her child to go to college to become a teacher. I floundered for many years and finally became a preschool teacher at the age of 54. I couldn't be happier now, but I was so unproductive and dissatisfied with my career for 30 years.
I regret listening to a therapist about my son’s gender fluid play and my lack of early support and understanding about it.

1.)I would be less afraid. my life is turning out just fine. I worried about so many things and 99% of them did not happen.

2.)I wish I could have lived by A Course in Miracles earlier in my life. It's still a daily (or each minute) struggle. The goal is to listen to the holy spirit and not your ego.
Never studying abroad during college. It would have been an opportunity to actually live in another country and learn the language better!

My regret is not dreaming bigger and being bolder when I was in my late teens and 20's. The norms for women in the mid '70s to '80s were still a bit traditional. Thank goodness in my 30s I connected with a wonderful and wise mentor who helped me develop into the person I was meant to be, and I'm still developing personally and professionally even in my 60s. I try to pay it forward to those around me whenever the opportunity arises.

I regret pawning my flute. I loved my flute in high school but when I got to college and was broke I pawned it for $30 and never had the money to go back and get it. My mother worked so hard to pay for that instrument when I was in beginner band and I loved it so much. It was my prized possession. I know it sounds silly because it’s a “thing,” but it represented so much more - My mother supporting me and making payments on an instrument we couldn’t afford, hours an hours of practice learning to play, happy memories with my closest friends in marching band. Losing it is something I can’t change and I have a recurring dream about it.
Getting involved in on line intimate relationships.  It damaged the trust in my real relationship.  We recovered but I still feel guilt and shame from it.
Growing up too fast
Moving away from family and the area we have roots, and my family moving away, too.
Marring early
Committing adultery
Not creating an environment in which my children, as young adults, felt safe confiding important things in me.
Not dating early
I wish i could have written a letter to praise God for everything he has done
Getting married to my ex husband
Not taking more risks
I regret leaving the love of my life
Having to trust someone so blindly.
I wish I had deliberately planned my career and finances when I was much younger

1. Never followed my gut feeling and was often let down because of that.
2. Did not sleep with many women when they offered themselves to me.  Was too naive & faithful.  Learned the hard way when my ex was unfaithful.
I regret not pursuing a better education, taking care of my health and my relationships and taking better care of my finances
I regret not having tried out more new things. Always worrying about looking “stupid”.
I regret not being more sociable while studying. I didn't participate much in events, organizations, and hang outs early
I regret chickening-out of a fist fight back in high school.
de no haber empezado a cuidarme antes
that I am not bigger fighter
I said some very bad words about another person when i was very young and I have regretted saying those words for a very long time.

I regret having children since I am not suited to care for them, and since I believe the world is becoming a chaotic and frightening place, more so for each year. I also regret not venturing out in the world in my youth, which leaves me immature and dependent. So in summary, I regret not having actively tried to evolve as a human being when there was better chances of succeeding without affecting the lives of others so much.
That I wasted my 20s without a clear career direction. I wish I had committed sooner.
lamento no haber demostrado mas mi cariño a mis amigos y familia

Could have been kind to family specially during my initial days after graduation 

Could have taught my kids my mother language
Didn’t make a girlfriend in secondary school life.

Feeling forced to choose a “female” profession and stick with it as my forever job. This career would be a gap filler on the way to raising a family and taking care of my husband. It was understood I would be giving it up or maintaining it part time to suit family life.

Not study outside Brazil.
Not try to change my career at 30 years old
Vbkk vbbhg
I regret skipping out of college. I had a decent professional life, however, not having graduated makes me sometimes feel less worthy than peers with a college education.
Did not do some decisions
Not hard working for my objectives earlier
I regret trying to be like my older brothers, as opposed to being my own man.
